.March 18th, 1927.
Sin scnd herewith. copy of the Presidents
frocla,naton, dated this day by the effect Of which
you will perceive that the trade between the Uni
ted States and certain colonial ports of Great
Britain, as opened by the act Of Congress, of the
first of March, 1923, entitled j" An act to regu-
late the commercial intercourse between the Uni
ted States and certain British colonial ports, is
closed and that the provisions of the act of A.
pril the eighteenth, 1918, entitled "An act con-
cerning Navigation,' and those of the act of May
the fifteenth, 1920, entitled an act, supplementary
to an act entitled An act concerning Navigation,'"
are in force. These several acts have heretofore
been transmitted to you at periods when their pro-
visions were in operation, but copies Of them are
again enclosed for your information and govern
ment.


AS British vessels from some of the colonial
ports specified in the first section of the act of the
first OF March, 1898, may now be within the United
States. and consequently, must have arrived ante
ror to the date of the Proclamation, the President
directs, that all such British vessels be allowed to
depart from our ports with their cargoes. As 9TH
ers may arrive between the date of the Proclama-
ton, and the time Of its reaching you, he also d-
rects, that, to these, the forfeitures and penal
ties of the aforesaid acts of April the 18th, 1878,
and May the 18th, 1920, be not enforced: but that
they. too, be permitted to depart. And if, after
you shall have received the Proclamation, British
vessels should arrive within the ports of the United
States from some one or more of the said British
Colonial ports, in ignorance of the existing prohi-
bition, which the laws impose to their entry, the
President further directs, that, in the case of all
British vessels arriving prior to the first day Of
July next, you cause notice to be given to them, as
soon as possible, of the prohibitions accompanied by
orders for their departure within twenty tour hours
without unlading; upon their failure to comply
with which orders, you will proceed to enforce
against them the provisions of the acts last rected.
In case Of all British vessels arriving within our
ports, from any Of the aforesaid British colonial
ports, after the first Of July, you will. forthwith
enforce against them the provisions Of those acts.
/ have the honor to remain,


Your obedent servant,


RICHARD IRISH

forgotten all his prophecies of 1894, and how they

We must confess that the "powers that be' at

The srord; for he says he intends to employ OUR
rifle against Them" But perhaps, after all, the

Baltimore, March IS
THE RAIL ROAD-Bv referring TO advertising
columns, il will be that the Commissioners will open
books for subscription the Rail Road Stock, at the
Mechanics Bank on Tuesday next The Stock is divided
into thirty thousand shares of one hundred dollars each
ten thousand of which for subscription BY the
State five thousand for the city If Baltimore. and fifteen
thousand to be taken by individuals and public bodies
One dollar per share is to be paid subscribing, and the
residue in such instaments, and at such times may be
required BY the President and Directors but not more
than third Of the can be demanded IN any
one year from the commencement of the work and before
any payment can be demanded sixty days notice must be
given These terms are very liberal and will the
books to be filled, have no doubt, on the first day.


Patriot


Baltimore March IA


THE RAIL ROAD-We publish to day the charter of
the Baltimore and Ohio Rail Road Company The work
has really begun earnest and we doubt no will be pro
secuted with energy to successful and glorious result
The advantages of Rail Road to Baltimore, to the Wes
tern country and to the people on the whole route
will be almost ncalculable Besides the immense saving
in the of transporting articles that now come to our
Market many such the coal of the Aleganysa to be
equal in quality to any in use, and inexhaustibe in
quantty,-and the -four Of the West, that now Cannot
reach u.s. will find their this Market and constitute
with us articles Of commerce These, however, are
bu articles, Of hundreds, that will cross the Ae-
ganes both uays for the first tine the Rail Road The
advantages Of Rail Road over canal may seem require
illustration in this place. In another paragraph We have
noticed the fact that the people on the banks OF the great
York Canal shipping their produce for Baltimore
by way of the snsquehanna in OF the canal



ter as we'll in summer and it is III the former season
that the Western merchants visit the sea ports to lay
their stocks, they will of resort to the Rail Road
instead of waiting or three months for the opening OF
the canal. Ill


1t is believed that the contemplated Rail Road will be-
come the successful rival of the NewY0rk Cans for the
reasons above stated and that other project could sue
ceed in competition with that great work. for the I'M
prize Of the Western Trade Succeeding IN obtain
ing this Trade, moe,y Of il, what must not the
advantages be, that this great work will confer on Ba-
more The prosperity Of fNew-York will no longer be un
rvalled-no the glory conferred upon her by her canals
without parallel. As said yesterday, we believe the
stock will be Immediately takenthe second branch OF ee
City Council perceive. has promptly passed reso
ion subscribe for the shares (5000S50o reser
we'd the City by the charter, and we have little doubt
that the other branch will give its sanction to It with equal
spirit and promptness. 70.

Baltimore. March IS.

The language which the Delaware Gazette
applies to the present Administration is disgusting
to nine tenths of its readers in this County 1t by
no means speaks the sentiments Of the party who
support that paper, the Federalists here, as well
as the Democrats, almost unanimously approve Of
the measures of government, and entertain just
displeasure at the groundless opposition which is
made to them by certain set of politicians. who,
it is feared have other object in view, than their
own interest and advancement to Offices. Ofseven
or eight of Mr.. Harker's subscribers in my mme-
diate neghborhood, not one of them is opposed to
Mr.. Adams, and they will do all in their power to
promote his reelection, and as most of them
of sound Judgment, good education, correct prnci
ples and strict integrity, and their opinions al
ways have great weight and influence, their efforts
will not be fruitless. You may rely upon it, that
Mr.. Harker, in endeavoring to produce an impress
sion that the Administration is unpopular in Sussex
is guilty of an attempt to deceive his readers Kent
County is also for Adams, 8 to 10.


We are aware that MIR. Harker labors ndefati-
gably to abuse Mr.. Adams-and we are also aware
that he once labored indefatigably to abuse Gen
eral jackson. and he has given such evidence Of
the unsettled state of his principles and the insta-
bility Of his opinions with regard to presidential af


fairs, that his labors to promote injure the
of any candidate for the chief magistracy, are but
Of little consequence"

widow of the late General JoHN STEELE, in the 70h year

RY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED oTATES,
PROCLAMATION.


| WHEREAS by the sixth section of an act Of Con-
press entitled can act to regulate the commercial
Intercourse between the United States and certain
British Colonial ports," which was approved on
,he first day Of March, in the year Of our Lord
1928 it is enacted that this act, unless repealed
altered or amended, by Congress, shall be and
continue in force 80 long as the above enumerated
British colonial ports shall be open to the admis-
sion Of the vessels of the United States, conform
aby to the provisions of the British act of Parla
ment, of the twentyfourth of June last, being the
forty fourth chapter of the Acts OF the third year
Of George the fourth But if at any time the trade
and intercourse between the United States and all
or any Of the above enumerated British colonial
ports, authorized by the said act of Parliament,
should be prohibited by British Order in Council,
or by act of Parliament then, from the day OF the
date Of such Order in Council, or act Of Parlia
ment, or from the time that the same shall com
mence to be in force, proclamation to that effect
having been made by the President OF the United
States, each and every provision Of this act, so far
as the same shall apply to the intercourse between
the United States and the above enumerated Bri


sh colonial ports, in British vessels, shall cease
to operate in Their favor; and each and every pro-
vision Of the Act concerning Navigation ap.
proved on the eighteenth of April, one thousand
esht hundred and eighteen, and of the act supple
mentary thereto, approved on the fifteenth OF May,
one thousand eight hundred and twenty, shall re-
yye and be in full force"


And whereas, by an act of the British Parlla-
ment, which passed the fifth day Of July, in the
year of our Lord 1926, entitled 6 An act to re-
pea the several Laws relating to the Customs"
the said act Of Parliament Of the Gath OF June,
1922, was repealed; and by another act of the
British Parliament, passed OH the fifth day OF July,
in the year of our I.or, 1925, in the sixth year OF
the reign of George the Fourth entitled " An act
10 regulate the trade of the British possessions
abroad" and by an order Of His Britannia Majes.
" in Council, bearing date the 27th Of July, 1926,
the trade and intercourse authorized by the aore-
said act of Parliament, of the Gath OF June, 1922,
between the Omitted States and the greater part of
the said British colonial ports therein enumerated,
have been prohibited upon aud from the first day
Of December last past, and the contingency has
thereby arisen on which the President Of the u
nited States was authorized by the sixth section
aforesaid Of the act of Congress Of lst March,
1928, to issue proclamation to the effect therein
mentioned:


Now, therefore, I, JOHN QuINcY ADAMS. Pre-
sIent Of the United States of America, do hereby
declare and proclaim that the trade and inter-
course authorized by the sai, act of Parliament Of
the Oath of June, 1922, between the United States
and the British colonial ports enumerated III the
aforesaid act of Congress Of the st Of March, 1898
have been, and are, upon and from the LIST day OF
December 1896, by the aforesaid two several acts
Of Parliament, of the 9Th of July. 1925. and by
the aforesaid British Order in Council of the eth
day of July, 1926, prohibited.


Given under hand at the City Of Washington this


18th day of March, in ihe year of Lord 1897, and


the ffty-Hrs. Of the Independence of the United


States.


JOHN QUINCY ADAMS
BY the President:


H. CLAY,


Secretary of State.


Washington, March II.
THE PRESIDENTS PROCLAMATION.
After the matter for paper was prepared
ton on the subject Of the Colonial Trade, which
we this day publish. The law, it should seem.
does not authorize the President to issue his Pro
camation to take effect prospectively: but such
steps will of course be taken by the Executive as
candor and equity require, in regard to such ves-
aels as are now in port, or may arrive in the Uni
ted States without having received previous knowl-
edge of the Presidents Proclamation.
We certainly could have wished that Congress
should SO have left this matter that the British
government might have seen distinctly, and in the
form of law, the terms on which the United States
we're willing to open the Colonial Trade to both
parties, and had full time for the consideration Of
those terms. AS Congress, however, saw fit to
pass no new law, it has only remained for the Ex-
ecutive to carry into execution such laws as do ex-
is, according to its sense of duty The contin.
gency provided for by existing laws has happened,
and Congress having risen without altering those
laws nothing has remained to the Executive but to
give ,efectto those laws, in conformity with their
requirement.. Journal

ond street, Philadelphia.


The Unpriucipled Opposition. ."-We have al
ready published Mr.. Giles's famous resolutions Of
fered in the House of Delegates of Virginia, and
informed our readers Of their passage in that.body
They have also passed the Senate, in which body
Mr.. Cabell moved new resolution, as follows:


"rhat the Legislature of Virginia will sustain the Cen
era Government in the exercise Of its legitimate powers


The resolution was adopted 12 to 10. So it
seems that in the Senate of Virginia there are ten
men whose opposition to the present administration
is so unprincipled and rancorous, that they have
declared their determination not to support it even
in :" the exercise of its Legitimate powers."-
They have ayowed their intention to endeavor to
thwart every measure recommended by, or having
the sanction of, Mr.. Adams or his cabinet, though
their opposition should produce an irreparable in
Jury to the country.


The Administration and its friends have nothing
to fear from such opponents. On the contrary, a
course of conduct like that Of the ten Senators of
the s. Old Domininn,o will cause the friends of
the constitution, the lovers Of good order, the sup
porters Of Domestic Manufactures and Internal
improvements. to rally to the support ofan admin
,stration opposed by men of such stamp. tits
impossible that the sober and rejecting part OF the
community can unite with those who will oppose
every measure calculated to promote the general

CIRCULAR TO THE COLLECTORS.


TREASURY DEPARTMENT.
full articles.article:
.March 18th, 1927.
Sin scnd herewith. copy of the Presidents
frocla,naton, dated this day by the effect Of which
you will perceive that the trade between the Uni
ted States and certain colonial ports of Great
Britain, as opened by the act Of Congress, of the
first of March, 1923, entitled j" An act to regu-
late the commercial intercourse between the Uni
ted States and certain British colonial ports, is
closed and that the provisions of the act of A.
pril the eighteenth, 1918, entitled "An act con-
cerning Navigation,' and those of the act of May
the fifteenth, 1920, entitled an act, supplementary
to an act entitled An act concerning Navigation,'"
are in force. These several acts have heretofore
been transmitted to you at periods when their pro-
visions were in operation, but copies Of them are
again enclosed for your information and govern
ment.


AS British vessels from some of the colonial
ports specified in the first section of the act of the
first OF March, 1898, may now be within the United
States. and consequently, must have arrived ante
ror to the date of the Proclamation, the President
directs, that all such British vessels be allowed to
depart from our ports with their cargoes. As 9TH
ers may arrive between the date of the Proclama-
ton, and the time Of its reaching you, he also d-
rects, that, to these, the forfeitures and penal
ties of the aforesaid acts of April the 18th, 1878,
and May the 18th, 1920, be not enforced: but that
they. too, be permitted to depart. And if, after
you shall have received the Proclamation, British
vessels should arrive within the ports of the United
States from some one or more of the said British
Colonial ports, in ignorance of the existing prohi-
bition, which the laws impose to their entry, the
President further directs, that, in the case of all
British vessels arriving prior to the first day Of
July next, you cause notice to be given to them, as
soon as possible, of the prohibitions accompanied by
orders for their departure within twenty tour hours
without unlading; upon their failure to comply
with which orders, you will proceed to enforce
against them the provisions of the acts last rected.
In case Of all British vessels arriving within our
ports, from any Of the aforesaid British colonial
ports, after the first Of July, you will. forthwith
enforce against them the provisions Of those acts.
/ have the honor to remain,


Your obedent servant,


RICHARD IRISH

We wonder Corporal Harker does not take les
sons from experience. Has our modern Samuel
forgotten all his prophecies of 1894, and how they
we're not fulfleda He then prophecied that Mr..
Crawford would have eleven votes more than suf-
ficient to elect him.


We must confess that the "powers that be' at
Washington, are in some danger-provided, the
Corporal uses the rifle with as much skill as he does
The srord; for he says he intends to employ OUR
rifle against Them" But perhaps, after all, the
Corporal's rifle is as harmless as goose quill.


We have seen, in Mr.. Crawford's case, how far
/" alr' Mr.. Harker's "po,cer' can 60 towards
putting man p:-we must endeayor to wait
patiently little while, when we shall see how far
g alr' his sspover" can go towards putting man
dorn.

full articles.headline: Baltimore. March IS.
full articles.article:
Baltimore, March IS
THE RAIL ROAD-Bv referring TO advertising
columns, il will be that the Commissioners will open
books for subscription the Rail Road Stock, at the
Mechanics Bank on Tuesday next The Stock is divided
into thirty thousand shares of one hundred dollars each
ten thousand of which for subscription BY the
State five thousand for the city If Baltimore. and fifteen
thousand to be taken by individuals and public bodies
One dollar per share is to be paid subscribing, and the
residue in such instaments, and at such times may be
required BY the President and Directors but not more
than third Of the can be demanded IN any
one year from the commencement of the work and before
any payment can be demanded sixty days notice must be
given These terms are very liberal and will the
books to be filled, have no doubt, on the first day.


Patriot


Baltimore March IA


THE RAIL ROAD-We publish to day the charter of
the Baltimore and Ohio Rail Road Company The work
has really begun earnest and we doubt no will be pro
secuted with energy to successful and glorious result
The advantages of Rail Road to Baltimore, to the Wes
tern country and to the people on the whole route
will be almost ncalculable Besides the immense saving
in the of transporting articles that now come to our
Market many such the coal of the Aleganysa to be
equal in quality to any in use, and inexhaustibe in
quantty,-and the -four Of the West, that now Cannot
reach u.s. will find their this Market and constitute
with us articles Of commerce These, however, are
bu articles, Of hundreds, that will cross the Ae-
ganes both uays for the first tine the Rail Road The
advantages Of Rail Road over canal may seem require
illustration in this place. In another paragraph We have
noticed the fact that the people on the banks OF the great
York Canal shipping their produce for Baltimore
by way of the snsquehanna in OF the canal



ter as we'll in summer and it is III the former season
that the Western merchants visit the sea ports to lay
their stocks, they will of resort to the Rail Road
instead of waiting or three months for the opening OF
the canal. Ill


1t is believed that the contemplated Rail Road will be-
come the successful rival of the NewY0rk Cans for the
reasons above stated and that other project could sue
ceed in competition with that great work. for the I'M
prize Of the Western Trade Succeeding IN obtain
ing this Trade, moe,y Of il, what must not the
advantages be, that this great work will confer on Ba-
more The prosperity Of fNew-York will no longer be un
rvalled-no the glory conferred upon her by her canals
without parallel. As said yesterday, we believe the
stock will be Immediately takenthe second branch OF ee
City Council perceive. has promptly passed reso
ion subscribe for the shares (5000S50o reser
we'd the City by the charter, and we have little doubt
that the other branch will give its sanction to It with equal
spirit and promptness. 70.


Bolirsrs March 15-In the First Branch of the City
Council, last evening, the Committee to whom had been
referred the Resolution from the other branch authorizing
subscription of FIVE hundred thousand dollars to the Rail
oadnade report recommending the passage Of he said
Resoluion The report subsequently discussed and
laid the table by vote of Is to 9. We informed
there is no doubt of its final passage. american.


Baltimore, March 16-Our readers will be gratifed to
learn that the First Branch of the City Council has passed
the Resolution (from the other Rranch directing sub.
scrpon Of FIVE hundred thousand dollars to the stock OF
the Baltimore ard Ohio Rail Road Company. Inc vote
was 20 for, and against it. .7me7tcan.

full articles.headline:
Ertract of letter to the Editors Of the Watchnun


dated in Susser County, DEL, March Is, 1897
full articles.article:
The language which the Delaware Gazette
applies to the present Administration is disgusting
to nine tenths of its readers in this County 1t by
no means speaks the sentiments Of the party who
support that paper, the Federalists here, as well
as the Democrats, almost unanimously approve Of
the measures of government, and entertain just
displeasure at the groundless opposition which is
made to them by certain set of politicians. who,
it is feared have other object in view, than their
own interest and advancement to Offices. Ofseven
or eight of Mr.. Harker's subscribers in my mme-
diate neghborhood, not one of them is opposed to
Mr.. Adams, and they will do all in their power to
promote his reelection, and as most of them
of sound Judgment, good education, correct prnci
ples and strict integrity, and their opinions al
ways have great weight and influence, their efforts
will not be fruitless. You may rely upon it, that
Mr.. Harker, in endeavoring to produce an impress
sion that the Administration is unpopular in Sussex
is guilty of an attempt to deceive his readers Kent
County is also for Adams, 8 to 10.


We are aware that MIR. Harker labors ndefati-
gably to abuse Mr.. Adams-and we are also aware
that he once labored indefatigably to abuse Gen
eral jackson. and he has given such evidence Of
the unsettled state of his principles and the insta-
bility Of his opinions with regard to presidential af


fairs, that his labors to promote injure the
of any candidate for the chief magistracy, are but
Of little consequence"

Proposals have Just been issued for publishing
in this Borough, semi-weekly newspaper to be
entitled the :. Deiamare Journnl' 1t is to be
edited by NJ BRADFORD. Esq, formerly Editor
Of the Delaware Gazette, and will support the
Administration.

full articles.headline:
BY THE PREsIDENT or THE UNITED STATES,


PROCLAMATION.
full articles.article:
RY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED oTATES,
PROCLAMATION.


| WHEREAS by the sixth section of an act Of Con-
press entitled can act to regulate the commercial
Intercourse between the United States and certain
British Colonial ports," which was approved on
,he first day Of March, in the year Of our Lord
1928 it is enacted that this act, unless repealed
altered or amended, by Congress, shall be and
continue in force 80 long as the above enumerated
British colonial ports shall be open to the admis-
sion Of the vessels of the United States, conform
aby to the provisions of the British act of Parla
ment, of the twentyfourth of June last, being the
forty fourth chapter of the Acts OF the third year
Of George the fourth But if at any time the trade
and intercourse between the United States and all
or any Of the above enumerated British colonial
ports, authorized by the said act of Parliament,
should be prohibited by British Order in Council,
or by act of Parliament then, from the day OF the
date Of such Order in Council, or act Of Parlia
ment, or from the time that the same shall com
mence to be in force, proclamation to that effect
having been made by the President OF the United
States, each and every provision Of this act, so far
as the same shall apply to the intercourse between
the United States and the above enumerated Bri


sh colonial ports, in British vessels, shall cease
to operate in Their favor; and each and every pro-
vision Of the Act concerning Navigation ap.
proved on the eighteenth of April, one thousand
esht hundred and eighteen, and of the act supple
mentary thereto, approved on the fifteenth OF May,
one thousand eight hundred and twenty, shall re-
yye and be in full force"


And whereas, by an act of the British Parlla-
ment, which passed the fifth day Of July, in the
year of our Lord 1926, entitled 6 An act to re-
pea the several Laws relating to the Customs"
the said act Of Parliament Of the Gath OF June,
1922, was repealed; and by another act of the
British Parliament, passed OH the fifth day OF July,
in the year of our I.or, 1925, in the sixth year OF
the reign of George the Fourth entitled " An act
10 regulate the trade of the British possessions
abroad" and by an order Of His Britannia Majes.
" in Council, bearing date the 27th Of July, 1926,
the trade and intercourse authorized by the aore-
said act of Parliament, of the Gath OF June, 1922,
between the Omitted States and the greater part of
the said British colonial ports therein enumerated,
have been prohibited upon aud from the first day
Of December last past, and the contingency has
thereby arisen on which the President Of the u
nited States was authorized by the sixth section
aforesaid Of the act of Congress Of lst March,
1928, to issue proclamation to the effect therein
mentioned:


Now, therefore, I, JOHN QuINcY ADAMS. Pre-
sIent Of the United States of America, do hereby
declare and proclaim that the trade and inter-
course authorized by the sai, act of Parliament Of
the Oath of June, 1922, between the United States
and the British colonial ports enumerated III the
aforesaid act of Congress Of the st Of March, 1898
have been, and are, upon and from the LIST day OF
December 1896, by the aforesaid two several acts
Of Parliament, of the 9Th of July. 1925. and by
the aforesaid British Order in Council of the eth
day of July, 1926, prohibited.


Given under hand at the City Of Washington this


18th day of March, in ihe year of Lord 1897, and


the ffty-Hrs. Of the Independence of the United


States.


JOHN QUINCY ADAMS
BY the President:


H. CLAY,


Secretary of State.


Washington, March II.
THE PRESIDENTS PROCLAMATION.
After the matter for paper was prepared
ton on the subject Of the Colonial Trade, which
we this day publish. The law, it should seem.
does not authorize the President to issue his Pro
camation to take effect prospectively: but such
steps will of course be taken by the Executive as
candor and equity require, in regard to such ves-
aels as are now in port, or may arrive in the Uni
ted States without having received previous knowl-
edge of the Presidents Proclamation.
We certainly could have wished that Congress
should SO have left this matter that the British
government might have seen distinctly, and in the
form of law, the terms on which the United States
we're willing to open the Colonial Trade to both
parties, and had full time for the consideration Of
those terms. AS Congress, however, saw fit to
pass no new law, it has only remained for the Ex-
ecutive to carry into execution such laws as do ex-
is, according to its sense of duty The contin.
gency provided for by existing laws has happened,
and Congress having risen without altering those
laws nothing has remained to the Executive but to
give ,efectto those laws, in conformity with their
requirement.. Journal

ond street, Philadelphia.


The Unpriucipled Opposition. ."-We have al
ready published Mr.. Giles's famous resolutions Of
fered in the House of Delegates of Virginia, and
informed our readers Of their passage in that.body
They have also passed the Senate, in which body
Mr.. Cabell moved new resolution, as follows:


"rhat the Legislature of Virginia will sustain the Cen
era Government in the exercise Of its legitimate powers


The resolution was adopted 12 to 10. So it
seems that in the Senate of Virginia there are ten
men whose opposition to the present administration
is so unprincipled and rancorous, that they have
declared their determination not to support it even
in :" the exercise of its Legitimate powers."-
They have ayowed their intention to endeavor to
thwart every measure recommended by, or having
the sanction of, Mr.. Adams or his cabinet, though
their opposition should produce an irreparable in
Jury to the country.


The Administration and its friends have nothing
to fear from such opponents. On the contrary, a
course of conduct like that Of the ten Senators of
the s. Old Domininn,o will cause the friends of
the constitution, the lovers Of good order, the sup
porters Of Domestic Manufactures and Internal
improvements. to rally to the support ofan admin
,stration opposed by men of such stamp. tits
impossible that the sober and rejecting part OF the
community can unite with those who will oppose
every measure calculated to promote the general
| lfar
